original_data.question: A junior orthopaedic surgery resident is completing a carpal tunnel repair with the department chairman as the attending physician. During the case, the resident inadvertently cuts a flexor tendon. The tendon is repaired without complication. The attending tells the resident that the patient will do fine, and there is no need to report this minor complication that will not harm the patient, as he does not want to make the patient worry unnecessarily. He tells the resident to leave this complication out of the operative report. Which of the following is the correct next action for the resident to take?
original_data.augmented_question:
Here's a paraphrased version of the medical text:

A junior orthopaedic surgery resident is assisting with a carpal tunnel repair under the supervision of the department chairman, who serves as the attending physician. During the procedure, the resident accidentally cuts a flexor tendon, which is successfully repaired without issues. However, when informed by the attending that the patient will recover fully and won't be harmed by the minor complication, the resident is advised not to include this in the operative report, fearing it might cause unnecessary distress for the patient. In light of this situation, what should the resident do next?

options.A: Disclose the error to the patient and put it in the operative report
options.B: Tell the attending that he cannot fail to disclose this mistake
options.C: Report the physician to the ethics committee
options.D: Refuse to dictate the operative report

model_response:
{'A': 'Disclose the error to the patient and put it in the operative report', 'B': 'Tell the attending that he cannot fail to disclose this mistake', 'C': 'Report the physician to the ethics committee', 'D': 'Refuse to dictate the operative report'}

Answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>
